2022年是迎難而上的一年。

2022年伊始，全球經濟環境一片暗淡。新冠病毒變異株Omicron肆虐，令全球經濟增長繼續受壓，通脹壓力亦持續上升。其後俄羅斯與烏克蘭爆發衝突，進一步推高通脹壓力，導致各主要央行採取前置式貨幣緊縮政策，擴大環球金融市場的波動，並加劇經濟增長放緩的風險。本地方面，第五波疫情爆發，感染個案急速上升，亦進一步打擊經濟。同時，圍繞防疫措施與檢疫限制的負面報道，更令外界對香港產生誤解，威脅香港作為國際金融中心的聲譽。全年計，香港實質本地生產總值收縮了3.5%。

儘管面對重重挑戰，金管局繼續致力保障香港貨幣與金融穩定，並於主要策略範疇推進多項有利發展的措施，進一步鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位。經歷3年的旅遊限制後，我們成功向國際社會展示香港已全面復常，旅客亦能再次親身訪港體驗。金管局在去年11月舉辦「國際金融領袖投資峰會」，來自世界各地的金融領袖親身來港出席。外界如此熱烈的反應，成為印證香港全面復常最好不過的證明。

展望未來，外圍環境仍然充滿前所未有的不確定性。儘管如此，內地經濟重啟會為香港以至整個地區重新注入動力。金管局將繼續緊守崗位，履行維持香港貨幣與銀行體系穩定的職能，並積極尋求更多有利香港發展的機會，展現及提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。我們亦會繼續為提升全球氣候應變能力及可持續發展出力。今年除《二零二二年年報》外，我們會另外發表《二零二二年可持續發展報告》，以便更詳細地介紹金管局在提升香港作為綠色和可持續金融樞紐的地位所進行的各項工作，以及金管局作為負責任投資者及可持續機構所作出的努力。

# 貨幣及金融體系：堅穩如昔

聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）自1983年實施至今，歷經多個經濟周期，成功抵禦各種各樣的外來衝擊。2022年再次見證聯匯制度的抗震能力。在美國聯邦儲備局（聯儲局）大幅收緊貨幣政策下，弱方兌換保證於2022年5月至11月期間被觸發41次，金管局按照既定機制，以有序及具透明度的方式從市場買入合共2,421億港元。其間港元匯率及貨幣市場繼續運作暢順，反映聯匯制度穩健有效。

這份對聯匯制度的信心，來自於建立多年的穩固根基。正如國際貨幣基金組織在其《2022年對外部門報告》中重申，聯匯制度的公信力建基於多項因素，包括具高透明度的運作規則、充裕的外匯儲備、審慎的財政制度、穩健的金融監管，以及靈活的經濟結構。

我們深信除了穩健的機制外，致力與公眾及市場溝通以加深其對聯匯制度的了解、進行有效的市場監察，以及就不同情景作出應變計劃，均有助鞏固各界對聯匯制度的信心。我們就聯匯制度運作機制推出的社交媒體宣傳活動，有助在年內弱方兌換保證多次被觸發的情況下，有效維護市場對聯匯制度的信心。內部方面，金管局亦善用數據分析技術加強市場監察，讓我們能適時回應最新市場形勢。

年內，儘管面對宏觀層面的挑戰以及遞增的信用風險，香港銀行體系仍然維持穩健，資本及流動性均非常充裕。2022年底，本地銀行的綜合總資本充足比率為20.1%，遠高於國際最低要求的8%。2022年第4季，大型銀行的流動性覆蓋比率稍升至162.3%，亦遠高於法定最低要求的100%。鑑於信貸環境面對挑戰，銀行體系的資產質素略為轉差，特定分類貸款比率於2022年底升至1.38%，但有關水平仍屬穩健，並低於2000年以來的長期平均水平1.8%。

# 銀行體系：有效監管確保運作穩健

疫情持續3年，來自各方面的挑戰均有所加劇，例如地緣政治緊張局勢升溫及主要央行收緊貨幣政策。然而，全賴多年來妥善的風險管理及有效的監管，香港銀行體系得以維持穩健，繼續發揮支持經濟的重要作用。

過去一年面對的一項主要監管挑戰，是在第五波新冠疫情後經濟仍充滿不確定性之下，確保銀行繼續為客戶提供所需支援的同時，維持穩健的信用風險管理。「預先批核還息不還本」計劃進一步展期，並加入自願性部分本金還款選項，讓借款人可以選擇開始償還部分本金，協助客戶就最終回復正常還款作好準備。

因應主要經濟體大幅收緊貨幣政策令市場波動加劇，2022年金管局另一項主要監管工作是加強監察銀行的市場及流動性風險承擔。我們深入評估各經濟體同步收緊貨幣政策對銀行可能產生的影響，並就壓力測試引入新情景，以評估銀行應對長時間流動性壓力的韌性。

與此同時，我們繼續採取具前瞻性的措施，促進在多個範疇的有效風險管理。在運作穩健性及網絡防衛能力方面，我們提供指引協助銀行制定綜合及全面的運作架構，以達致穩健經營，並就銀行具體的運作範疇提供詳盡監管指引，例如因應雲端技術普及而就使用雲端運算提供指引。此外，因應數碼化加速發展，我們亦加強了應對「網絡釣魚」騙案和推進消費者及投資者保障的工作。

除了維持銀行體系穩健外，金管局亦致力推動普及金融及提高銀行服務的便利性。銀行對於金管局就提供基本銀行服務的呼籲反應正面，有銀行在新發展地區的大型公共屋邨增設分行及自助銀行服務設施。受到疫情相關的旅遊限制影響，許多香港市民無法使用其內地銀行戶口。有見及此，金管局與有關各方緊密合作，協助重新啓動約50萬個內地銀行戶口，受影響戶口持有人無需親身前往內地辦理。

另一個對銀行業持續發展具策略重要性的範疇是提升專業能力。為擴展業務，銀行業對專業人才的需求仍然龐大。金管局在其人才發展策略 — 「連接人才與未來」— 的基礎上，在過去一年推出多項措施，協助銀行業吸引、培育及挽留人才，集中提升及再培訓現有從業員的技能，以及培育年輕一代，以建立可持續的人才庫。

# 國際金融中心：香港重回國際舞台!

實施多時的疫情相關旅遊限制於2022年逐步撤銷，我們作出了多方面的努力讓香港重回國際舞台。11月舉行的「國際金融領袖投資峰會」吸引超過200位來自環球金融機構的國際及地區負責人親臨香港，並獲得全球各地的關注及熱切迴響。儘管峰會舉行日期不巧遇上50年來首個在11月份發出的8號颱風訊號，峰會仍然十分成功，向世界傳遞了香港已全面復常並正展現無比朝氣與活力的有力訊息。我們很高興看到峰會產生了正面的漣漪效應，不少環球金融機構及國際組織現正或計劃在香港舉辦各類活動。

除吸引各地訪客重臨香港外，我和金管局的同事體會到面對面交流聯繫的重要性，因此盡可能親身代表香港出席主要國際會議，積極參與全球政策討論，並藉外訪機會與環球金融機構的集團管理層會面，加深他們對香港穩健的金融體系以及在「一國兩制」下香港提供的各種機遇的了解。

為確保香港保持作為國際金融中心的競爭力，我們在金融科技、內地機遇，以及綠色和可持續金融等策略性重點領域不斷開拓市場新界限。我們亦進一步加強本港的金融平台，提供頂尖的服務，吸引更多企業落戶香港。有關金管局在綠色和可持續金融方面的工作詳情，請參閱《二零二二年可持續發展報告》。

# 金融科技

繼2021年6月公布「金融科技2025」策略，2022年我們在五大範疇均取得顯著進展。

我們在「全面推展銀行數碼化」方面的工作取得理想成果。根據金融科技應用評估的結果，香港銀行業在不同業務領域廣泛採用金融科技，而且所採用的科技類別亦持續增加。我們自2017年以來逐步推廣及支持數碼化的工作獲銀行積極回應，並持續取得成果，成續令人鼓舞。我們將繼續與業界緊密合作，根據評估的結果，進一步推動金融科技在特定銀行業務領域的應用及促進個別科技類別的發展。

年內我們在央行數碼貨幣方面的工作邁進重要的新里程。「多種央行數碼貨幣跨境網絡」(mBridge)項目進入試行階段，並成為全球其中一個率先為企業跨境交易進行真實結算的央行數碼貨幣項目。在零售層面，數字人民幣跨境使用的技術測試已進入第二階段，主要測試通過「轉數快」為數字人民幣錢包增值。數碼港元方面，我們將採取三軌道方式為將來可能發行數碼港元作好準備，並推出第二軌道先導計劃，邀請業界深入研究數碼港元可行的應用場景。

數據可全面釋放金融科技的潛力。我們於去年10月推出的「商業數據通」正是提升香港數據基建的重要一步。作為以數據擁有人授權為本的共享數據基建，「商業數據通」能方便金融機構提取企業的商業數據，使企業（尤其中小型企業）更容易獲得融資。截至2022年底，「商業數據通」已促成超過1,000宗中小企貸款，總額逾19億港元。

最後，我們在擁抱金融創新和它帶來的好處的同時，亦明白有必要監察及處理好相關發展可能帶來的風險。我們正密切注視虛擬資產領域的發展，並參與相關監管事宜的國際討論。經考慮公眾諮詢收集到的意見及相關國際標準後，我們將採納「相同風險，相同監管」1 的方式制定穩定幣的監管制度及界定其監管範圍。未來我們率先規管的對象將是那些標榜與一種或以上法定貨幣的價值掛鈎的穩定幣，因為這類穩定幣可能對貨幣及金融穩定帶來更高及更迫切的潛在風險。我們相信在訂立適當的規範下，業界將可更安全穩妥地開拓數碼金融的潛力。

科技正重塑我們的未來。金管局與銀行業界正積極準備迎向這個「新常態」。我們有信心我們正構建的金融科技生態圈將有助全面釋放金融科技的潛力，並提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。

# 內地機遇
en:
2022 was a year of resilience.

At the start of 2022, the global economic environment was bleak. The Omicron variant of the coronavirus continued to disrupt global economic growth and fuel rising inflation. Subsequently, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine further intensified inflationary pressures, prompting major central banks to adopt tighter monetary policies, which increased volatility in global financial markets and heightened the risk of an economic slowdown. Locally, a fifth wave of the pandemic led to a rapid increase in infections, further impacting the economy. Simultaneously, negative reports surrounding COVID-19 restrictions created a perception of Hong Kong abroad, threatening its reputation as an international financial center. For the year, Hong Kong's real Gross Domestic Product contracted by 3.5%.

Despite facing numerous challenges, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to ensure Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability, implementing key measures to reinforce its position as a leading international financial center. Following three years of travel restrictions, we have successfully demonstrated to the international community that Hong Kong has fully reopened, welcoming visitors to experience the city once again. Last November, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority hosted the "International Financial Leaders Investment Summit," attracting financial leaders from around the world. The enthusiastic response from the international community is a clear indication of Hong Kong’s full recovery.

Looking ahead, the external environment remains fraught with unprecedented uncertainty. Nevertheless, the resumption of economic activity on the Mainland will boost Hong Kong and the wider region. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will continue to steadfastly fulfill its role in maintaining the stability of Hong Kong’s monetary and banking systems, and will actively seek opportunities to benefit Hong Kong’s development and enhance its competitiveness as an international financial centre. We will also continue to contribute to global climate resilience and sustainable development. In addition to the 2022 Annual Report this year, we will publish a separate 2022 Sustainability Report to provide a more detailed account of the HKMA’s work in enhancing Hong Kong’s position as a green and sustainable finance hub, as well as our efforts as a responsible investor and sustainable institution.

# Resilient and Steadfast as Ever

The Linked Exchange Rate System, implemented in 1983, has successfully weathered numerous economic cycles and absorbed various external shocks. In 2022, the system once again demonstrated its resilience. Amidst significant monetary policy tightening by the US Federal Reserve, the Hong Kong dollar’s exchange rate was defended 41 times between May and November 2022, triggering the system’s mechanism to ensure it remained within its permitted trading band. During this period, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority purchased a total of HKD 242.1 billion from the market, as per the established protocol. Throughout this time, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate and money market continued to operate smoothly, reflecting the stability and effectiveness of the arrangement.

The confidence in the linked exchange rate system stems from its solid foundation built over many years. As reaffirmed by the International Monetary Fund in its "2022 External Sector Report," the credibility of the linked exchange rate system is based on several factors, including transparent operating rules, ample foreign exchange reserves, prudent fiscal policies, sound financial regulation, and a flexible economic structure.

We firmly believe that, in addition to robust mechanisms, actively communicating with the public and the market to enhance their understanding of the linked exchange rate system, conducting effective market surveillance, and developing contingency plans for different scenarios all contribute to reinforcing confidence in the system across various sectors. Our social media promotional campaign launched to explain the operational mechanisms of the linked exchange rate system effectively maintained market confidence despite the weak-side exchange guarantee being triggered multiple times this year. Internally, the HKMA also utilizes data analytics technology to strengthen market surveillance, enabling us to respond promptly to the latest market developments.

The Hong Kong banking system remained stable throughout the year, maintaining ample capital and liquidity despite facing macroeconomic challenges and rising credit risks. At the end of 2022, the consolidated capital adequacy ratio of local banks stood at 20.1%, significantly above the international minimum requirement of 8%. In the fourth quarter of 2022, the liquidity coverage ratio of major banks slightly increased to 162.3%, also well above the statutory minimum requirement of 100%. Given the challenging credit environment, the asset quality of the banking system deteriorated slightly, with the classified loan ratio rising to 1.38% by the end of 2022. However, this level remained sound and was still below the long-term average of 1.8% since 2000.

# Effective Regulation Ensures Banking System Health.

The pandemic has persisted for three years, exacerbating challenges stemming from heightened geopolitical tensions and tightening monetary policies by major central banks. However, thanks to years of prudent risk management and effective regulation, Hong Kong’s banking system has remained resilient and continues to play a crucial role in supporting the economy.

Banks continued to provide necessary support to customers while maintaining sound credit risk management amid economic uncertainty following the fifth wave of the pandemic. The pre-approved interest-only payment plan with deferred principal was further extended, and now includes a voluntary option for borrowers to begin repaying part of the principal, helping customers prepare for resuming normal repayments.

In response to increased market volatility caused by significant tightening of monetary policies by major economies, a key regulatory focus for the HKMA in 2022 was to strengthen the supervision of banks’ market and liquidity risk exposures. We conducted in-depth assessments of the potential impact of synchronized monetary tightening across economies on banks, and introduced new scenarios for stress testing to evaluate banks’ resilience to prolonged liquidity pressures.

We continue to implement proactive measures to strengthen risk management across multiple areas. To enhance operational resilience and digital defense capabilities, we provide guidance to banks in establishing comprehensive operational frameworks to ensure stable and effective operations. This includes detailed regulatory guidance for specific operational areas, such as addressing the use of cloud computing as digitalization expands. Furthermore, in response to the accelerating pace of digitalization, we have reinforced our efforts to combat phishing scams and protect consumers and investors.

In addition to maintaining the stability of the banking system, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to promoting financial inclusion and enhancing the convenience of banking services. Banks have responded positively to the HKMA’s call to provide basic banking services, with some establishing new branches and self-service banking facilities in new development areas, particularly in large public housing estates. Due to pandemic-related travel restrictions, many Hong Kong residents have been unable to use their mainland bank accounts. To address this, the HKMA has closely collaborated with relevant parties to reopen approximately 500,000 mainland bank accounts, allowing affected account holders to do so without traveling to the mainland.

The continued development of Hong Kong's banking sector hinges on strengthening professional expertise. As banks grow, the demand for skilled professionals remains high. Building on its "Connecting Talent with the Future" talent development strategy, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has introduced several initiatives over the past year to attract, develop, and retain talent within the industry. These initiatives focus on upgrading the skills of existing employees and nurturing the next generation to build a robust talent pipeline.

# International Financial Center: Hong Kong Reclaims Its Global Stage.

Hong Kong has worked diligently to return to the global stage since the gradual lifting of pandemic-related travel restrictions in 2022. The “International Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit,” held in November, drew over 200 senior executives from leading global financial institutions, attracting considerable international attention and enthusiastic responses. Despite coinciding with the first November typhoon signal in half a century, the summit was a resounding success, demonstrating to the world that Hong Kong has fully rebounded and is brimming with renewed energy and opportunity. We are encouraged to see the summit’s positive impact, with numerous global financial institutions and international organizations now hosting or planning events in Hong Kong.

Beyond attracting visitors to return to Hong Kong, my colleagues at the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and I recognize the importance of face-to-face communication. Therefore, I strive to represent Hong Kong in person at major international conferences, actively participate in global policy discussions, and use overseas trips as opportunities to meet with the management teams of global financial institutions to deepen their understanding of Hong Kong’s robust financial system and the opportunities offered under the “One Country, Two Systems” framework.

To ensure Hong Kong maintains its competitiveness as an international financial center, we are actively developing new opportunities in strategic areas such as financial technology, leveraging opportunities in the Mainland, and advancing green and sustainable finance. We are also strengthening Hong Kong’s financial ecosystem to provide leading services and attract more businesses to Hong Kong. For details on the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s work in green and sustainable finance, please refer to the “2022 Sustainability Report.”

# Financial Technology

In 2022, we made significant progress across all five areas following the release of the "FinTech 2025" strategy in June 2021.

Hong Kong banks have made significant progress in their digital transformation. According to a recent assessment of fintech adoption, the banking sector has widely embraced fintech across various business areas, with the range of technologies used consistently expanding. Since 2017, our efforts to support and drive forward digitalization have been well-received by banks and continue to deliver positive outcomes. We will continue to collaborate closely with the industry, leveraging the assessment results to further promote fintech applications in specific banking areas and to encourage the development of individual technology categories.

This year, we have made significant progress in our work on central bank digital currencies. The “Multi-Border Framework for Interlinking Payment Systems” (mBridge) project has entered a pilot phase and is among the first globally to facilitate real-time settlement for cross-border corporate transactions using central bank digital currencies. At the retail level, technical testing of cross-border use of the digital yuan has entered its second phase, primarily testing the recharge of digital yuan wallets via the Faster Payment System. Regarding the digital Hong Kong dollar, we will adopt a three-track approach to prepare for its future issuance and launch a pilot program for the second track, inviting industry participants to explore viable application scenarios.

Data can fully unlock the potential of financial technology. Our “Commercial Data Platform,” launched in October last year, is an important step in enhancing Hong Kong’s data infrastructure. As a shared data infrastructure based on data owner authorization, the “Commercial Data Platform” enables financial institutions to access business data, making it easier for companies, particularly SMEs, to obtain financing. As of the end of 2022, the “Commercial Data Platform” helped secure over 1,000 SME loans, totaling over HKD 1.9 billion.

Finally, while embracing financial innovation and its benefits, we recognize the need to monitor and manage the associated risks. We are closely observing developments in the virtual asset sector and participating in international discussions on related regulatory matters. After considering public consultation feedback and relevant international standards, we will apply the principle of “same risk, same regulation” to establish a regulatory framework for stablecoins and define its scope. Our initial focus will be on stablecoins pegged to the value of one or more fiat currencies, as these pose the most immediate risks to monetary and financial stability. We believe that with appropriate regulations, the industry can safely and securely explore the potential of digital finance.

Technology is reshaping our future. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the banking sector are actively preparing for this "new normal." We are confident that the fintech ecosystem we are building will help fully realize the potential of fintech and enhance Hong Kong's competitiveness as an international financial center.

# 2022年摘要

# 經濟及金融環境

受第五波新冠病毒疫情、金融狀況收緊及充滿挑戰的外圍環境等多項不利因素的影響，香港經濟在2022年顯著收縮。勞工市場首先轉差，其後逐步改善，而通脹則維持溫和。受惠於內地與香港全面通關，預計2023年香港經濟增長將由低位復甦。

香港銀行體系在2022年繼續保持穩健，資本及流動性狀況維持充裕，資產質素繼續處於健康水平。

# 貨幣穩定

隨着美國收緊貨幣政策，港元轉弱，弱方兌換保證於年內被多次觸發。然而，港元外匯及貨幣市場繼續保持有序及暢順運作，一再證明聯繫匯率制度穩健有效。

# 儲備管理

2022年的投資環境異常動盪，多種資產類別的價格同時下挫，外匯基金錄得整體投資回報率為負4.5%，與市場上大部分多元資產基金的表現相比，虧損幅度相對溫和。

金管局亦繼續致力推動負責任投資及資產多元化。與此同時，長期增長組合自2009年開展投資以來的內部回報率年率為12.6%。

# 銀行體系穩定

面對金融市場波動擴大，金管局加強對銀行的信用及市場風險管理的監管，並與銀行緊密合作，提升銀行的運作穩健性及網絡防衛能力，以應對網絡威脅持續增加及銀行業數碼轉型步伐加快的情況。

金管局進一步推出有關「先買後付」產品及新增物業轉按支付安排的消費者保障措施。此外，金管局與其他監管機構合作制定虛擬資產監管架構，並就分銷投資產品發出指引及推出全新的信託業務監管制度。有關個人信貸資料的「多間信貸資料服務機構」模式下的「信貸資料平台」亦於年內啟用。

金管局繼續與銀行合作提升香港的打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集（反洗錢）生態系統，並加強對騙案的回應措施，又透過「反洗錢合規科技實驗室」系列進一步推動數據與科技的應用，以及加快金管局就反洗錢工作採用監管科技的步伐。

金管局在本地實施有關資本充足標準及披露標準等國際監管標準方面取得良好進展。金管局亦與銀行業共同為未來發展努力建立可持續的人才庫及提升從業員的技能。

為確保香港備有具公信力的處置機制，金管局制定新處置標準，又進行地區危機模擬演習，並在所有具本地系統重要性銀行建立一層新的吸收虧損能力資源，為處置機制的發展立下重要的里程碑。

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

「國際金融領袖投資峰會」取得成功，鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位，並製造正面的漣漪效應。

中國人民銀行與金管局之間的貨幣互換協議於年內優化，進一步鞏固香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位。金管局亦與其他監管機構及持份者合作，籌備開通「互換通」，及推出配合人民幣計價股票在港交易的雙櫃台莊家機制。另又致力發展債務工具中央結算系統成為亞洲區主要的國際中央證券託管平台。

在加強香港金融平台的競爭力方面取得良好進展，涵蓋債券發行、資產及財富管理、企業財資中心，以及綠色和可持續金融等範疇。

金管局亦繼續推行「金融科技2025」策略，促進金融業界採用金融科技，並提升香港作為金融科技樞紐的地位。快速支付系統「轉數快」隨着功能提升，使用量穩步增長。

# 機構職能

金管局透過不同渠道與社會及市場保持有效聯繫，提升公眾對金管局政策及工作的了解。

對內，金管局悉心建立一支強調靈活應變及可持續發展的工作團隊，同時遵守嚴格的財政紀律及提升資訊科技能力，應對變化及確保有效執行各項政策及措施。

# 2022 Review

# Economy and Finance

Hong Kong’s economy contracted significantly in 2022, facing headwinds from the fifth wave of the COVID-19 pandemic, tightening financial conditions, and a challenging external environment. The labor market initially weakened but gradually improved, while inflation remained moderate. With the resumption of travel between the Mainland and Hong Kong, economic growth is expected to recover from a low base in 2023.

Hong Kong’s banking system remained sound in 2022, with ample capital and liquidity, and asset quality maintained a healthy level.

# Financial Stability

As the United States tightened its monetary policy, the Hong Kong dollar weakened, triggering the linked exchange rate system multiple times during the year. However, Hong Kong's foreign exchange and money markets continued to operate smoothly and in an orderly manner, repeatedly demonstrating the system’s stability and effectiveness.

# Inventory Management

The investment environment in 2022 was exceptionally volatile, with prices across multiple asset classes declining simultaneously. The Foreign Exchange Fund recorded an overall investment return of -4.5%, a modest loss compared to the performance of most diversified asset funds in the market.

The HKMA continues to promote responsible investment and asset diversification. The long-term growth portfolio has generated an annualized return of 12.6% since 2009.

# Banking System Stable

In response to expanding volatility in financial markets, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has strengthened its oversight of banks' credit and market risk management, and is working closely with banks to enhance their operational resilience and cybersecurity capabilities, in order to address the increasing cyber threats and the accelerated digital transformation of the banking sector.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has further introduced consumer protection measures concerning “buy now, pay later” products and arrangements for refinancing mortgages. In addition, the HKMA has collaborated with other regulatory bodies to develop a regulatory framework for virtual assets, issued guidelines on the distribution of investment products, and launched a new regulatory regime for trust business. A credit data platform under the “multiple credit reference agencies” model for personal credit data will also be operational this year.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to collaborate with banks to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, strengthening measures to address fraud and accelerating the adoption of regulatory technology in its AML efforts. Through a series of RegTech Labs, the HKMA is also promoting the application of data and technology to enhance its anti-money laundering framework.

The Monetary Authority has made good progress in implementing international regulatory standards, including those relating to capital adequacy and disclosure, locally. It is also working with the banking sector to build a sustainable talent pool and enhance the skills of its workforce.

To ensure Hong Kong has a credible resolution mechanism, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority developed new resolution standards, conducted regional crisis simulation exercises, and established a new layer of loss-absorbing capacity resources for systemically important banks operating in Hong Kong, marking an important milestone in the development of the resolution framework.

# Hong Kong: A Global Financial Hub

The International Financial Leaders Investment Summit was a success, strengthening Hong Kong's position as a global financial hub and generating positive impacts.

The currency swap agreement between the People's Bank of China and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority was enhanced this year, further solidifying Hong Kong's position as a global offshore RMB business hub. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is also collaborating with other regulators and stakeholders to prepare for the launch of Swap Connect and to introduce a mechanism supporting RMB-denominated stock trading in Hong Kong through dual market makers. Furthermore, efforts are underway to develop the central clearing system for debt instruments into a major international Central Securities Depository (CSD) platform for the Asia region.

Significant progress has been made in strengthening Hong Kong’s competitiveness as a financial hub, covering areas such as bond issuance, asset and wealth management, corporate treasury centers, and green and sustainable finance.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to implement its "FinTech 2025" strategy, promoting the adoption of financial technology within the financial sector and enhancing Hong Kong's position as a FinTech hub. The fast payment system "FPS" (轉數快) has seen steady growth in usage as its functionality is enhanced.

# Organizational Roles and Responsibilities

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority engages with the public and the market through various means to enhance understanding of its policies and work.

Internally, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has cultivated a team emphasizing adaptability and sustainable development, while maintaining strict financial discipline and strengthening IT capabilities to respond to changes and ensure the effective implementation of policies and measures.

金管局公布優化人民幣流動資金安排，包括擴大規模及簡化操作。

# 1月28日

金管局與證券及期貨事務監察委員會（證監會）發出聯合通函，就中介人從事虛擬資產相關活動提供更新指引以保障客戶。

# 1月28日

金管局就銀行管理與虛擬資產及虛擬資產服務提供者相關的洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集風險的監管指引作出更新。

# 2月8日

金管局宣布延長「銀行業人才起動計劃」6個月。

# 2月23日

香港按揭證券有限公司（按揭證券公司）全資擁有的香港按證保險有限公司（按證保險公司）宣布，按揭保險計劃就已落成住宅物業作出修訂及擴大適用範

# 2月23日

「百分百擔保個人特惠貸款計劃」推出優化措施（4月19日生效），並將申請期延長至2023年4月底。

# 2月23日

金管局聯同「銀行業中小企貸款協調機制」宣布，延長「預先批核還息不還本」計劃6個月至10月底，貿易融資貸款本金還款期則可獲延長90天。計劃亦同時提供一個為期一年的部分本金還款選項，讓有意願和有能力的借款人逐步回復正常還款。

「中小企融資擔保計劃」亦推出優化措施（4月1日生效），並將申請期延長至2023年6月30日。

# 4月1日

金管局及保險業監管局（保監局）推出措施就利用保費融資投購人壽保單加強客戶保障。

# 4月14日

金管局就協助香港市民在因疫情而實施的檢疫限制下重新啟動其內地銀行帳戶，向香港銀行發出指引。

# 4月26日

金管局推出「合規科技資訊平台」，以鼓勵香港合規科技生態圈加強在應用合規科技方面的經驗及專門知識交流。

# 4月28日

金管局宣布與銀行業聯合推出「銀行業畢業生培訓計劃」，為銀行業的快速增長領域擴大人才庫。

# 5月5日

金管局認可由香港銀行公會（銀行公會）和接受存款公司公會將實施的「強制性背景查核計劃」，旨在處理香港銀行業中「滾動的壞蘋果」現象。

# 5月6日

「百分百擔保個人特惠貸款計劃」開始接受個別受暫緩追討欠租安排影響的業主申請，直至10月31日。

# 5月25日

金管局發表《零售銀行前線部門獎勵制度專題評估》的報告（英文版），以持續推動銀行業穩善文化。

# 5月27日

金管局發出《信託業務營運守則》及相關的《監管政策手冊》新單元，以加強規管與監管香港信託業務。

# 5月31日

按揭證券公司全資擁有的香港年金有限公司宣布，香港年金計劃推出優化措施及推廣優惠。優化措施包括提高「醫療和牙科開支特別款項提取」金額上限及個人保費總金額上限。

# 6月23日

金管局發布金融科技應用評估的結果及相關工作計劃，以進一步支持業界應用金融科技。

# 7月1日

為實施巴塞爾委員會的「銀行於基金的股權投資的資本要求」而制定的《2022年銀行業（資本）（修訂）規則》生效。

金管局參與設計和執行為期3日的區域危機模擬演習。該演習共涉及10間亞太區的中央銀行、監管和處置當局以及存款保險機構，旨在加強跨境合作。

# 7月8日

金管局就認可機構銷售保障型投資相連壽險提供指引，為客戶提供保障。

# 7月8日

金管局根據政府發表的《2022年香港洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集風險評估報告》所概述的主要見解及相關影響，向銀行及儲值支付工具持牌人發出指引。

# 7月20日

金管局歡迎銀行公會公布就住宅物業轉按交易提供多一種支付安排予客戶選擇。按揭銀行於11月7日開始提供該項新增的物業交易支付安排。

# 7月21日

金管局與數碼港在德勤協助下，合辦第二次「反洗錢合規科技實驗室(AMLab 2)，主要聚焦門檻較低及容易落實的「易用科技」。

# 9月2日

金管局就銀行的「先買後付」產品推出一系列消費者保護措施，以推動負責任借貸。

# 9月8日

金管局宣布推出一站式網上資源平台「銀行業導航」及第二屆「銀行業銜接課程」。

# 9月16日

金管局聯同「銀行業中小企貸款協調機制」宣布，延長「預先批核還息不還本」計劃3個月至2023年1月底。

同日，按證保險公司宣布，「中小企融資擔保計劃」下的還息不還本安排亦相應延長，借款企業可申請延遲償還本金合共最多36個月。

# 9月26日

金管局敲定「金融科技從業員培訓資助先導計劃」的實施細則，並正式在銀行業界啟動計劃。

# 9月27日

證監會與金管局發表有關持牌法團和註冊機構銷售非交易所買賣投資產品的第二次年度聯合調查結果，共有327間持牌法團及63間註冊機構呈報它們在2021年內銷售投資產品的相關數據，總交易額達50,150億港元，參與的投資者增加5%至770,000名。

# 9月27日

金管局在「銀行專業資歷架構」下推出「合規」單元，與銀行業界合作制定一套可供業界共同採用和具透明度的能力標準，以提升從事合規工作的從業員的專業能力。

金管局聯同銀行公會、銀行及儲值支付工具業界支持香港警務處推出詐騙陷阱搜尋器「防騙視伏器」，以加強預防、偵測及制止社會上的詐騙行為及減少公眾的財務損失。

除了發出實務指引和更新相關的「常見問題」外，金管局亦與銀行及儲值支付工具業界合作，通過網頁及社交媒體上的消費者教育資訊，提高公眾的防騙意識，並發布《匯思》文章闡述這方面的工作。

# 10月20日

金管局聯同「銀行業中小企貸款協調機制」宣布，延長「預先批核還息不還本」計劃6個月至2023年7月底，並優化部分本金還款選項，協助有能力的企業準備日後逐步回復正常還款。

金管局發出兩份通告，以更新銷售及分銷彌補虧損產品的相關要求，及就合適性評估提供指引。

金管局與數碼港合作，並由德勤協助，舉辦第三次「反洗錢合規科技實驗室(AMLab 3)。AMLab 3建基於過往AMLab系列的成果，運用網絡分析應對欺詐風險及減低傀儡戶口網絡騙案所造成的損失。

# 12月7日

金管局就將於2023年6月生效的《2022年打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集（修訂）條例草案》向銀行發出通告，闡明與銀行業相關的最新修訂。

# 12月15日

金管局為銀行及儲值支付工具業界舉辦打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集（反洗錢）講座，內容涵蓋監管要求的更新、反洗錢監管科技和合規科技、財富來源的監管要求、可疑交易報告的反饋及打擊大規模毀滅武器擴散資金籌集風險的更新。

金管局、保監局和強制性公積金計劃管理局聯合發布通函，概述3間監管機構首度聯合展開有關中介人銷售兩種可扣稅產品手法（即合資格延期年金保單和強制性公積金可扣稅自願性供款）的喬裝客戶檢查計劃的主要結果和從中觀察到的良好做法。

所有香港的具本地系統重要性銀行已建立一層新的財務資源以備在處置時吸收虧損，標誌着金管局在提升這類銀行的處置可行性及銀行體系穩健性上立下里程碑。

金管局與瑞士聯邦財政部轄下的瑞士聯邦國際金融事務秘書處在線上合辦第五次香港與瑞士金融合作對話。

金管局再次獲任命為財務行動特別組織轄下評估及合規小組聯席主席，任期兩年。財務行動特別組織是反洗錢全球標準制定組織。

按揭證券公司宣布與14間合作銀行簽訂基建貸款合作框架《諒解備忘錄》，就基建貸款上的合作定立主要準則。

# Record of Major Events in 2022

# monetary stability

The government issued HK$500 million in 20-year Hong Kong dollar government bonds through a tender under its Institutional Bond Issuance Program.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued an updated commitment statement, reaffirming its commitment to abide by the updated version of the Global Foreign Exchange Market Guidelines when acting as a market participant.

The HKMA announced enhanced arrangements for RMB liquidity, including expanding the scale and simplifying procedures.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has updated its regulatory guidance on money laundering and terrorist financing risks related to banking activities and virtual asset service providers.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced a six-month extension of the "Banking Sector Talent Development Scheme."

# February 23

The "100% Guaranteed Personal Preferential Loan Program" has introduced improvements (effective April 19) and extended the application period to the end of April 2023.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the Banking Sector SME Loan Coordination, announced an extension of the Interest-Only Repayment Scheme for six months until the end of October. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Insurance Authority have introduced measures to enhance customer protection when purchasing life insurance policies with premium financing.

# April 28

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced a joint initiative with the banking industry to launch the Banking Industry Graduate Training Program, expanding the talent pool for the sector's rapidly growing sectors.

# May 5th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has approved a “Mandatory Background Check Scheme” to be implemented by the Hong Kong Association of Banks (HKAB) and the Association of Deposit-Taking Companies, designed to address the issue of problematic individuals within the Hong Kong banking sector.

# May 6th

The "100% Guaranteed Concessionary Loan Scheme" is now accepting applications from individual landlords affected by the temporary deferral of rent collection, until October 31st.

#May25th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has published a report on incentive schemes for frontline staff in retail banks to further promote a sound banking culture.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has issued guidelines for trust business operations and a new section of the Regulatory Policy Handbook to strengthen oversight of trust businesses in Hong Kong.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has issued guidelines for authorized institutions on the sale of guaranteed investment-linked life insurance policies to protect customers.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued two notices to update requirements for the sale and distribution of products designed to mitigate losses and to provide guidance on suitability assessments.

# 2023年工作重點及前瞻

儘管香港經濟在2023 年初出現復甦跡象，但外圍環境仍然充滿挑戰及不確定性。近期美國和歐洲的銀行業受壓，個別美國本土銀行在2023 年3 月倒閉，對環球金融市場造成漣漪效應，而主要央行收緊貨幣政策，很有可能令2023 年全球經濟增長放緩甚或衰退。另一方面，地緣政治局勢緊張，以及去全球化的威脅持續，可能會繼續拖累全球貿易，並會令環球金融市場不時出現波動。儘管如此，香港金融體系憑藉多年來所建立穩健的抗震能力及充裕的緩衝，有足夠能力抵禦不利衝擊。

金管局非常重視保障貨幣及金融穩定。展望未來，面對不明朗的宏觀經濟環境，金管局會保持警惕，力求迅速辨識正浮現的風險，並靈活應對。與此同時，金管局會繼續把握機遇及創造政策空間，進一步提升香港作為主要國際金融中心的地位。面對充滿挑戰的投資環境，金管局在管理外匯基金時會繼續審慎投資，同時保持足夠靈活性，按需要採取防禦措施，並維持高流動性。

# 金融體系保持穩定健全

環球經濟前景仍受制於重大的不確定因素。金管局會密切注視最新發展，提高警覺，防範各種潛在風險，以維持金融體系穩定健全；這是關乎持續提供關鍵金融服務的先決條件，因此亦是維繫香港經濟正常運作的命脈。

# 對潛在風險保持警惕

在2023年，美國利率未來走勢的不確定性，以及在先進經濟體銀行體系出現的壓力，可能會對主要先進經濟體的增長前景帶來下行風險。此外，持續的地緣政治風險，可能會繼續拖累全球貿易，並會令環球金融市場不時出現波動。然而，香港金融體系憑藉過去多年所建立的抗震能力及緩衝，有足夠能力抵禦不利衝擊。金管局亦有能力、資源及決心維持香港貨幣及金融穩定。

金管局將繼續密切注視本地及外圍環境的風險與脆弱性，並會按需要採取適當措施維持香港的貨幣及金融體系穩定。金管局亦會研究對香港經濟有影響的事項，以及評估與這些事項相關的潛在風險。

# 保持銀行體系穩定

鑑於地緣政治緊張局勢升級，以及各主要央行大幅加息以遏抑通脹，預計2023年銀行業的經營環境仍然充滿挑戰。另一方面，科技發展迅速及數碼化對銀行業來說既有危又有機。面對瞬息萬變的金融環境，金管局致力透過持續的監管工作確保銀行具足夠能力抵禦衝擊。與此同時，金管局亦會參照國際標準及最佳做法，繼續加強及優化銀行監管架構與政策。

# 風險為本的監管重點

# 信用、流動性及市場風險

在2023年，金管局將繼續密切注視認可機構的資產質素，並聚焦於認可機構的貸款分類及撥備做法，以及對財務狀況較差的借款人的管理。金管局亦會加強其監察系統，並採取積極措施確保銀行體系的整體信用風險水平維持可控。

另一方面，金管局會繼續留意企業的營運環境，並與銀行業及商界保持緊密溝通，以就最終退出「預先批核還息不還本」計劃作好準備，並同時確保暫時面對困難的客戶仍然得到適切的信貸支援。

此外，面對不明朗的宏觀經濟環境，金管局於2023年亦會加強監管認可機構的流動性及市場風險管理。

# 業務操作及科技風險

隨着銀行在業務營運中更廣泛應用科技，金管局會致力提升銀行業的運作穩健性及網絡防衛能力。繼5月發出《監管政策手冊》新單元「運作穩健性」後，金管局會與業界保持緊密聯繫，審視認可機構在制定運作穩健性框架方面的進度。同時，金管局將透過跟進認可機構在「網絡防衛評估框架2.0」評估下發現的問題以及檢視認可機構實施穩固三重數據備份的進展，提高銀行業的網絡防衛能力。

隨着數碼化的步伐加快，金管局的其他監管重點包括加強對銀行的第三方服務供應商風險管理的監管，以及提升銀行業的數據管治能力。

# 打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集

在2023年，金管局的工作重點包括更新監管資訊、加強打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集（反洗錢）生態系統各持份者的合作以應對洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集（洗錢）風險，以及進一步推動反洗錢監管科技與合規科技的發展。金管局的《打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集指引》亦會作出修訂，並會就「政治人物」採取與風險相稱的措施發出具體指引，從而促進業界以有效及風險為本的方法落實法例的主要修訂。與此同時，金管局會擴大現有公私營夥伴合作的涵蓋範圍以加強訊息共享，以及支持推出銀行之間的訊息共享平台，藉以加快偵測可疑戶口及防範戶口被濫用，並加強對騙案受害人的保障和協助受害人追討損失。金管局亦會透過「反洗錢合規科技實驗室」及其他反洗錢合規科技項目，進一步集中推動採用合規科技（包括數據分析），並致力發展宏觀分析能力，以配合其數據為本的反洗錢監管工作。透過實施上述各項措施，金管局將能更迅速針對傀儡戶口網絡等系統性洗錢風險採取相應措施，以及靈活應對不斷轉變的威脅。

# 財富管理業務

金管局在2023年會加強有關認可機構在財富管理以及銷售證券、強制性公積金（強積金）與其他投資及保險產品方面的操守的現場審查及非現場監察。2023年的重點將會是「跨境理財通」計劃、數碼分銷及諮詢平台、虛擬資產、環境、社會及管治(ESG)投資產品及長期保險產品。金管局在有關過程中會參考市場最新發展及國際標準的修訂。

金管局亦會與其他監管機構及銀行界緊密聯繫，並按需要就銷售投資、保險及強積金產品的監管標準向認可機構提供指引，其中亦會包括有關提供虛擬資產相關投資服務的指引。就此而言，為促進虛擬資產行業可持續及負責任地發展，金管局會積極參與相關國際組織，並與政府及其他金融監管機構合作，制定全面的虛擬資產監管架構。

隨着「跨境理財通」順利推出，金管局會與業界及相關監管機構聯繫，以優化該計劃。此外，金管局亦會與證券及期貨事務監察委員會（證監會）及業界合作，精簡投資產品銷售程序（包括適用於資深投資者的銷售程序），以及開始根據相關《監管政策手冊》新單元及新營運守則監管認可機構的信託業務。

# 監察金融市場基建

金管局的目標是按照《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）、《金融市場基建的原則》（《基建原則》），以及支付及金融基建委員會發出的各項指引促進其所監察的金融市場基建的安全及效率，按需要參照最新的國際標準評估各項基建。金管局會參與支付及金融基建委員會與國際證監會組織對實施《基建原則》的監察及評估計劃，亦會參與國際標準制定組織的工作，並參照國際慣例或因應市場及科技發展加強本身的監察規定。同時，如有需要，金管局會與有關當局合作，進一步加強合作監察安排。

# 制定政策

金管局會因應國際標準及最佳做法，繼續加強及優化銀行監管架構與政策。

# 在香港實施巴塞爾標準

# 資本標準

金管局會透過實施巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）近年發布的標準，進一步優化資本框架，當中包括：
- 2017年12月《巴塞爾協定三：危機後改革的最終方案》、2019年1月（2019年2月修訂）《市場風險最低資本規定》，以及2020年7月《信用估值調整風險架構具針對性的修訂》所載的經修訂資本標準 — 上述經修訂資本標準統稱《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案，載明信用風險、市場風險、信用估值調整風險及業務操作風險的新監管處理方法，並引入出項下限規定，以及優化槓桿比率框架。經過2022年的多輪業界諮詢後，金管局計劃在2023年就《銀行業（資本）規則》（《資本規則》）的建議修訂進行法定諮詢，以實施上述各項規定及正值中性逆周期緩衝資本。有關修訂預計於同年內提交立法會進行先訂立後審議程序，並不早於2024年1月1日生效，作為最低要求。
- 2022年12月《加密資產風險承擔的審慎處理方法》金管局計劃按照巴塞爾委員會的時間表，在2025年1月1日於本地實施有關標準，並打算於2023年就相關建議諮詢業界。

# 風險承擔限度

金管局於2023年3月就《銀行業（風險承擔限度）規則》的建議修訂諮詢業界。有關建議修訂主要是因應金管局實施上文提及的《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案下的經修訂資本標準而提出。諮詢文件亦包括就《資本規則》下有關官方實體集中風險的處理方法所作出的其他相應修訂。經修訂規則的目標實施日期將與落實《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案的經修訂《資本規則》中的信用風險部分的實施日期一致（即不早於2024年1月1日）。

# 流動性標準

金管局擬於2023年諮詢業界有關透過《2023年銀行業（流動性）（修訂）規則》（《2023年流動性修訂規則》）對《銀行業（流動性）規則》作出的建議修訂。相關修訂是因應同時期的《資本規則》建議修訂而作出，所以《2023年流動性修訂規則》的目標實施日期將與落實《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案的經修訂《資本規則》中的信用風險部分的實施日期一致（即不早於2024年1月1日）。

# 披露標準

《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案中與經修訂資本標準相關的新的及經修訂的披露規定，主要載於巴塞爾委員會分別於2018年12月及2021年11月發出的《第三支柱1 披露規定 — 更新框架》及《修訂市場風險披露規定》。巴塞爾委員會亦於2019年6月發出《修訂槓桿比率披露規定》，藉修訂槓桿比率的披露規定處理對潛在「粉飾櫥窗」（指銀行在報告日期前後減少某些交易的交易量，從而人為地提高報告及公開披露的槓桿比率）的關注。為在香港實施上述新的及經修訂的披露規定，金管局亦正擬備《銀行業（披露）規則》（《披露規則》）的相應修訂，以及經修訂後的標準披露模版及表格，並在過程中徵詢業界意見。預計《披露規則》的修訂將於2023年內連同《資本規則》的修訂一併提交立法會進行先訂立後審議程序。

# 2023 Priorities and Outlook

Despite signs of economic recovery in early 2023, Hong Kong’s economy faces a challenging and uncertain global environment. Recent pressures on the banking sectors in the United States and Europe, including the collapse of several U.S. banks in March 2023, have sent ripples through global financial markets. Furthermore, tightening monetary policies by major central banks could significantly slow global economic growth. Geopolitical tensions and the ongoing threat of deglobalization may also continue to weigh on global trade and cause market volatility. Nevertheless, Hong Kong’s financial system, built on years of robust resilience and substantial reserves, is well-positioned to weather these challenges.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority places great importance on safeguarding monetary and financial stability. Looking ahead, in the face of an uncertain macroeconomic environment, the HKMA will remain vigilant, promptly identifying emerging risks and responding flexibly. Simultaneously, the HKMA will continue to seize opportunities and create policy space to further enhance Hong Kong’s position as a leading international financial centre. In a challenging investment environment, the HKMA will continue to prudently manage the Exchange Fund, maintaining the flexibility to implement protective measures as required and ensuring high liquidity.

# The financial system is stable and robust.

The global economic outlook remains subject to significant uncertainties. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will closely monitor the latest developments, heighten vigilance, and guard against various potential risks to maintain a stable and sound financial system. This is a prerequisite for the continued provision of essential financial services and, therefore, the lifeline for Hong Kong’s normal economic operation.

# Stay vigilant to potential risks.

In 2023, uncertainty surrounding U.S. interest rate movements and pressures within the banking systems of advanced economies may pose risks to the growth prospects of major advanced economies. Furthermore, ongoing geopolitical risks could continue to weigh on global trade and lead to volatility in global financial markets. However, Hong Kong’s financial system, strengthened by the resilience and buffers built up over the years, is well-positioned to withstand adverse shocks. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also has the capability, resources, and determination to maintain monetary and financial stability in Hong Kong.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to closely monitor risks and vulnerabilities in both the local and external environments and will take appropriate measures as necessary to maintain the stability of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems. The HKMA will also study issues affecting the Hong Kong economy and assess the potential risks associated with them.

# Maintain the stability of the banking system.

Given the escalating geopolitical tensions and significant interest rate hikes by major central banks to curb inflation, the operating environment for the banking sector is expected to remain challenging in 2023. On the other hand, rapid technological advancements and digitalization present both opportunities and risks for the banking industry. In the face of a rapidly evolving financial landscape, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to ensuring banks have sufficient resilience to withstand shocks through ongoing supervision. At the same time, the HKMA will continue to strengthen and refine the banking regulatory framework and policies by referencing international standards and best practices.

# Risk-Based Regulatory Priorities

# Credit, Liquidity, and Market Risk

In 2023, the HKMA will continue to closely monitor the asset quality of authorized institutions, with a focus on their loan classification and provisioning practices, as well as the management of borrowers with weaker financial conditions. The HKMA will also strengthen its supervisory system and take proactive measures to ensure that the overall credit risk level of the banking system remains under control.

On the other hand, the HKMA will continue to monitor the operating environment of businesses and maintain close communication with the banking sector and the business community to prepare for the eventual withdrawal from the "interest-only repayment plan," while ensuring that customers facing temporary difficulties continue to receive appropriate credit support.

In response to the uncertain macroeconomic environment, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will strengthen its oversight of authorized institutions' liquidity and market risk management in 2023.

# Business and Technology Risks

As banks increasingly adopt technology in their business operations, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to enhancing the operational resilience and cybersecurity capabilities of the banking sector. Following the release of a new section on “Operational Resilience” in the Regulatory Policy Manual in May, the HKMA will maintain close communication with authorized institutions to review their progress in establishing operational resilience frameworks. Simultaneously, the HKMA will strengthen the banking sector’s cybersecurity capabilities by addressing issues identified under the “Cyber Resilience Assessment Framework 2.0” and reviewing the progress of authorized institutions in implementing robust triple data backups.

As digitalization accelerates, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's other regulatory priorities include strengthening oversight of banks’ third-party service providers’ risk management and enhancing data governance capabilities within the banking sector.

# Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing

In 2023, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will focus on updating regulatory information, strengthening collaboration among stakeholders to address money laundering and terrorist financing risks, and promoting the development of regulatory technology (RegTech) and compliance technology in anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing efforts. The HKMA will also revise its Guidelines on Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing, issuing specific guidance on risk-proportionate measures for politically exposed persons to facilitate the industry’s effective and risk-based implementation of key legislative amendments.
Concurrently, the HKMA will expand existing public-private partnerships to enhance information sharing and support the launch of an information-sharing platform among banks, accelerating the detection of suspicious accounts and preventing account misuse. This will also strengthen protection for victims of fraud and assist them in recovering losses.
The HKMA will further promote the adoption of compliance technology, including data analytics, through the AML/CTF RegTech Lab and related initiatives, striving to develop advanced analytical capabilities to support its data-driven regulatory oversight. Through these measures, the HKMA will be better positioned to swiftly address systemic money laundering risks, such as nominee account networks, and to flexibly respond to evolving threats.

# Wealth Management Services

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will strengthen on-site inspections and off-site supervision of authorized institutions regarding their conduct in wealth management, as well as the sale of securities, the Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF), and other investment and insurance products in 2023. Key areas of focus will include the "Cross-Border Wealth Management Connect" program, digital distribution and advisory platforms, virtual assets, environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investment products, and long-term insurance products. The HKMA will consider the latest market developments and revisions to international standards throughout this process.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will work closely with other regulatory bodies and the banking sector, providing guidance to licensed firms on regulatory standards for the sale of investment, insurance, and Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) products, including those related to virtual assets. To promote the sustainable and responsible development of the virtual asset industry, the HKMA will actively participate in relevant international organizations and collaborate with the government and other financial regulators to establish a comprehensive regulatory framework.

With the smooth launch of the "Cross-Border Wealth Management Connect," the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will liaise with the industry and relevant regulatory authorities to optimize the program. In addition, the HKMA will collaborate with the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) and the industry to streamline the sales procedures for investment products, including those applicable to sophisticated investors, and will begin regulating the trust business of authorized institutions in accordance with the new sections and operational guidelines in the relevant Regulatory Policy Manual.

# Financial Market Infrastructure Oversight

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority aims to promote the safety and efficiency of financial market infrastructures under its supervision, in accordance with the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the “Payment Ordinance”), the Principles for Financial Market Infrastructures (the “PFMI”), and the guidelines issued by the Payment and Financial Market Infrastructure Committee. The Authority assesses these infrastructures as needed, referencing the latest international standards. It participates in monitoring and evaluation programs conducted by the Payment and Financial Market Infrastructure Committee and the International Organization of Securities Commissions regarding the implementation of the PFMI, and engages in the work of international standard-setting organizations. The Authority also strengthens its oversight by adapting to market and technological developments and, where necessary, collaborates with relevant authorities to enhance supervisory cooperation.

# Developing Policy

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to strengthen and refine the banking regulatory framework and policies in line with international standards and best practices.

# Basel Standards in Hong Kong

# Capital Standards

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will further optimize its capital framework by implementing standards issued in recent years by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, including:
- The revised capital standards outlined in the December 2017 “Basel III: Finalizing Post-Crisis Reforms,” the January 2019 (revised in February 2019) “Minimum Capital Requirements for Market Risk,” and the July 2020 “Targeted Revisions to the Credit Valuation Adjustment Risk Framework” – collectively known as the Basel III final reforms. These reforms detail new regulatory approaches to credit risk, market risk, credit valuation adjustment risk, and operational risk, and introduce an output floor, as well as optimize the leverage ratio framework. Following multiple rounds of industry consultation in 2022, the HKMA plans to launch a public consultation in 2023 on proposed amendments to the Banking (Capital) Rules (“Capital Rules”) to implement these provisions and the countercyclical capital buffer. These amendments are expected to be submitted to the Legislative Council for pre-legislative scrutiny within the same year and will take effect no earlier than January 1, 2024, as minimum requirements.
- The December 2022 “Prudential Treatment of Crypto-Asset Exposures.” The HKMA plans to implement these standards locally on January 1, 2025, in line with the Basel Committee’s timeline, and intends to consult with the industry on related proposals in 2023.

# Risk Capacity

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) consulted the industry in March 2023 regarding proposed amendments to the Banking (Capital Adequacy Rules). These amendments primarily respond to the HKMA’s implementation of revised capital standards under the final Basel III reforms. The consultation document also includes related revisions to the handling of concentrated risk from government-related entities under the Capital Rules. The target implementation date for the revised rules will align with the implementation date of the credit risk component under the revised Capital Rules related to the final Basel III reforms (i.e., no earlier than January 1, 2024).

# Liquidity Standards

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) plans to consult the industry in 2023 regarding amendments to the Banking (Liquidity) Rules, introduced through the 2023 Banking (Liquidity) (Amendment) Rules (the “2023 Liquidity Amendment Rules”). These amendments are being made to coincide with proposed changes to the Capital Rules. Consequently, the target implementation date for the 2023 Liquidity Amendment Rules will align with the implementation date of the credit risk provisions in the revised Capital Rules under the final reforms of Basel III (i.e., no earlier than January 1, 2024).

# Reporting Standards

The final reform package of Basel III includes new and revised disclosure requirements related to revised capital standards, primarily detailed in the Basel Committee’s “Pillar 3 Disclosure Requirements – Updated Framework” (issued in December 2018) and “Revised Market Risk Disclosure Requirements” (issued in November 2021). The Basel Committee also issued “Revised Leverage Ratio Disclosure Requirements” in June 2019 to address concerns about potential “window dressing”—the practice of banks reducing transaction volumes around reporting dates to artificially inflate reported leverage ratios. To implement these requirements in Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is preparing corresponding amendments to the “Banking (Disclosure) Rules” (the “Disclosure Rules”), along with revised standard disclosure templates and forms, and is consulting with the industry in the process. These amendments to the Disclosure Rules are expected to be submitted to the Legislative Council for pre-legislative scrutiny together with amendments to the Capital Rules within 2023.

# 機構管治

金管局作為香港的中央銀行機構，深明良好的管治對維持及維護公眾對金管局履行其法定職責的信任及信心的重要性，因此一直致力秉持高水平的機構管治。

為實踐良好機構管治的承諾，金管局：
- 建立了一套清晰且具備高問責性的機構管治架構；
- 實施完善穩健的監控措施以管理風險，並確保所有職級員工的行為及其日常運作均符合指定標準；及
- 奉行具透明度及保持開放的政策，與各持份者保持緊密聯繫。

# 金管局與香港特別行政區政府

金管局是香港特別行政區政府（特區政府）架構的一部分，但可以按與公務員不同的聘用條款聘請員工，以吸引具適當經驗與專門知識的人才。金管局總裁及其員工均為公職人員。金管局的日常運作，在金融管理專員所獲賦予或轉授的法定權力範圍內高度自主。

財政司司長負責釐定香港的貨幣政策目標及貨幣體制：財政司司長於2003年6月25日致金融管理專員的函件中，訂明應透過貨幣發行局制度維持貨幣穩定，將港元匯率保持在約7.80港元兌1美元的水平。金融管理專員須自行負責達成貨幣政策目標，包括決定有關的策略、工具及執行方式，並負責維持香港貨幣制度的穩定與健全。

財政司司長在財經事務及庫務局局長的協助下，負責維持香港金融體系穩定與健全，以及保持香港的國際金融中心地位的政策。為推行這些政策，金融管理專員的職責包括：
- 促進銀行體系的整體穩定與有效運作；
- 與其他有關機構與組織合作，發展債務市場；
- 處理與法定紙幣及硬幣的發行及流通有關的事宜；
- 透過發展支付、結算及交收系統，以及在適當情況下負責操作有關系統，促進金融基建的安全與效率；及
- 與其他有關機構與組織合作，促進對香港貨幣及金融體系的信心，並推行適當的發展市場措施，以協助加強香港金融服務的國際競爭力。

外匯基金由財政司司長掌有控制權。金融管理專員須根據財政司司長轉授的權力，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 問責性與透明度

就日常運作及推行政府政策目標所採用的方法，金管局一直保持高度自主，並同時輔以高問責性及透明度。

金管局致力促進貨幣與銀行體系穩定，有效管理官方儲備，發展與監察穩健及多元化的金融基建，從而鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位，推動香港經濟發展。

金管局要有效履行職責，便必須取得社會人士的信任。因此，金管局以嚴謹的態度，履行向公眾解釋其政策及工作的責任，並盡力處理備受社會關注而涉及金管局職責範圍的事項。尤其，金管局透過傳統及社交媒體適時澄清有關金管局政策的失實資訊及謠言。

金融管理專員由財政司司長委任，因此金管局透過財政司司長向公眾負責；而由於金管局的職權由立法會通過的法律制訂，因此金管局亦透過立法會向公眾負責。金管局亦明白本身肩負更廣泛的責任，就是促進公眾對金管局角色及目標的認識，並密切留意社會人士所關注的事項。金管局在執行日常工作及與社會保持廣泛聯繫時，堅守盡力提高透明度及保持開放的政策。這項政策有兩大目標：
- 在顧及市場敏感性、商業秘密及機密資料披露的法定限制下，盡量使金融界及公眾充分了解金管局的工作；及
- 確保金管局掌握社會脈搏，並對公眾意見作出適當回應。

金管局在透明度方面致力達致國際最高標準，與傳媒保持廣泛聯繫之餘，亦出版各種中英文期刊及專題刊物。金管局的雙語網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)除有專門環節列載經濟研究、統計資料、監管資源、消費者資訊及其他課題外，還載有大量金管局出版的刊物、新聞稿、演辭及簡報會資料文件。此外，金管局又利用社交媒體平台，以能在數碼時代中更有效與公眾溝通。金管局辦事處設有資訊中心，分為圖書館及展覽館兩部分，每星期開放6日予公眾參觀及使用。有關金管局與公眾溝通及聯繫的工作，詳見「機構職能」一章（第157至162頁）。

金管局公布外匯基金及貨幣發行局帳目資料的次數，一直逐步增加，內容亦越趨詳細。金管局於1999年開始參與國際貨幣基金組織的中央銀行「數據公布特殊標準」計劃。金管局亦公布外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下貨幣發行委員會的會議紀錄，以及貨幣發行局制度運作報告。自1996年起，金管局網站載有銀行業監管政策及指引。

金管局與立法會的關係對提高問責性及透明度非常重要。金管局總裁承諾每年3次向立法會財經事務委員會簡報金管局各項工作及政策，並回答有關查詢。此外，金管局代表不時出席立法會事務委員會及小組委員會會議，闡釋及商討特別事項，以及協助議員審閱條例草案。

# 監控措施

金管局採用穩健有效的內部及外部監控機制，確保秉持高水平的員工操守、審慎的風險管理，以及適當的制衡。內部及外部審計職能就監控機制是否足夠及具成效提供獨立評估。

# 行為守則

《行為守則》就員工的道德與法律責任提供指引，確保所有職級員工的行為均符合指定標準。

# 內部監控

# 運作監控

作為風險管理的第一度防線，所有部門及分處均有責任評估其工作流程的風險，並制定適當的監控措施，確保金管局日常運作穩妥。

# 機構風險管理

風險管理亦在機構層面進行。由金管局總裁擔任主席的風險委員會，是機構風險管理架構的基石之一。

風險委員會審視和商討各部門所識別的潛在及新生風險，以及相關監控措施和緩解策略是否充足，並由該會定出適當的跟進行動。

# 內部審計

金管局內部審核處獨立評估不同部門的管治程序、風險管理及監控措施是否足夠及具成效，並提出改善建議。

# 外部審計

根據《外匯基金條例》第7條，外匯基金的財務報表由香港特區政府審計署審核。審計署並無就此項服務收取費用。經審核的外匯基金財務報表刊載於金管局《年報》。

# Organizational Governance

As Hong Kong's central banking institution, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority fully understands the importance of good governance in maintaining public trust and confidence in the Authority's statutory responsibilities. Therefore, it has consistently strived to uphold high standards of institutional governance.

To fulfill its commitment to sound institutional governance, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority:
- Has established a clear and highly accountable institutional governance framework;
- Has implemented comprehensive and robust monitoring measures to manage risks and ensure that the conduct of all staff complies with specified standards; and
- Maintains a policy of transparency and openness, maintaining close engagement with stakeholders.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is part of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government (the Government), but it can appoint staff under terms of employment different from those of civil servants to attract personnel with appropriate experience and expertise. The Chief Executive of the HKMA and its staff are all public officials. The HKMA operates with a high degree of autonomy in its daily operations within the legal authority delegated to the Financial Secretary.

The Financial Secretary is responsible for determining Hong Kong’s monetary policy objectives and monetary system. - Collaborating with other relevant institutions and organizations to develop the debt market;
- Handling matters relating to the issuance and circulation of legal tender notes and coins;
- Promoting the safety and efficiency of financial infrastructure through the development of payment, clearing, and settlement systems, and operating such systems where appropriate; and
- Collaborating with other relevant institutions and organizations to foster confidence in Hong Kong’s currency and financial system, and implementing appropriate market development measures to strengthen the international competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial services.

The Exchange Fund is under the control of the Financial Secretary. The Financial Manager is responsible to the Financial Secretary for the management and investment of the Exchange Fund, under the authority delegated by the Financial Secretary.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has consistently maintained a high degree of autonomy in its daily operations and in implementing government policy objectives, alongside strong accountability and transparency.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to maintaining monetary and banking stability, effectively managing official reserves, and developing and supervising a robust and diversified financial infrastructure, thereby consolidating Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre and fostering economic development in Hong Kong.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) must earn public trust to effectively carry out its duties. Therefore, the HKMA is committed to transparently explaining its policies and operations, and promptly addresses issues of public concern within its mandate. In particular, the HKMA clarifies misinformation and rumors regarding its policies through traditional and social media channels.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is appointed by the Financial Secretary and is therefore accountable to the public. The HKMA also derives its authority from laws passed by the Legislative Council, ensuring its accountability to the public through that body. The HKMA recognizes a broader responsibility to promote public understanding of its role and objectives, and to closely monitor matters of public concern. In its daily operations and engagement with the community, the HKMA is committed to enhancing transparency and maintaining an open policy. This policy has two main objectives:
- To ensure that the financial sector and the public are fully informed about the HKMA's work, while respecting legal restrictions on the disclosure of market-sensitive information, commercial secrets, and confidential data; and
- To remain attuned to public opinion and respond appropriately to public views.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to achieving the highest international standards in transparency. In addition to engaging with the media, the HKMA publishes a variety of bilingual journals and special publications. The HKMA’s bilingual website (www.hkma.gov.hk) features sections covering economic research, statistical data, regulatory resources, consumer information, and other topics, as well as publications, press releases, speeches, and briefing documents. Furthermore, the HKMA utilizes social media platforms to communicate more effectively with the public in the digital age. The HKMA’s office houses an Information Centre, divided into a library and an exhibition hall, which is open to the public six days a week. Details regarding the HKMA’s functions can be found in the “Institutional Functions” chapter (pages 157 to 162).

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has steadily increased the frequency and detail of its publications regarding the Exchange Fund and Currency Board accounts. The HKMA began participating in the International Monetary Fund’s Special Data Dissemination Standard (SDDS) for central banks in 1999. It also publishes minutes of meetings of the Currency Board Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, as well as reports on the operation of the Currency Board system. Since 1996, the HKMA’s website has featured banking sector supervisory policies and guidelines.

The relationship between the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Legislative Council is crucial for enhancing accountability and transparency. The HKMA Governor has committed to briefing the Legislative Council’s Financial Affairs Committee three times a year on the HKMA's operations and policies, and to answering related inquiries. In addition, HKMA representatives regularly attend Legislative Council committee meetings and sub-committee meetings to elaborate on and discuss specific issues, as well as assist legislators in scrutinizing draft legislation.

# 經濟及金融環境

面對第五波新冠病毒疫情、金融狀況收緊及充滿挑戰的外圍環境，香港經濟在2022年顯著收縮。勞工市場持續一段時間轉差，其後逐步改善，而通脹則維持溫和。資產市場亦有所受壓。受惠於內地與香港全面通關，預計2023年香港經濟增長將由低位復甦。

# 經濟回顧

# 實體經濟活動

受本地及外圍環境各項不利因素拖累，香港經濟在2022年收縮3.5%（表1及圖1）。本地方面，由於香港爆發第五波新冠病毒疫情，私人消費在第1季急跌，其後受惠於社交距離措施逐步放寬及政府消費券計劃的刺激，私人消費再度錄得按季增長。在營商氣氛疲弱及金融狀況收緊下，整體投資支出較2021年顯著下跌。對外方面，隨着外部需求轉弱，加上內地與香港之間的跨境陸路貨運受阻，香港貨物出口下挫。服務輸出依然大致疲弱，部分反映訪港旅遊活動低迷，但其後隨着政府於9月下旬撤銷抵港強制檢疫要求，情況於第4季稍為改善。

# 通脹

本地通脹壓力於2022年稍升，但仍屬溫和。具體而言，按年基本通脹率逐步上升至12月2%的溫和水平，其中外圍能源及食品價格高企的影響部分被溫和的本地成本壓力所抵銷，尤其是偏軟的房屋租金（圖2）。此外，在經濟活動疲弱下，名義工資增長及商業樓宇租金持續偏軟，亦有助遏抑通脹。2022年全年合計，基本及整體通脹率分別為1.7%及1.9%。

# 勞工市場

疫情下勞工市場狀況在2022年初急速惡化，但隨後持續改善。失業率在4月升至5.4%的高位後，於12月顯著回落至3.5%（圖3），當中大多數行業的失業率均有所下降。總就業人數（圖3）及私營機構職位空缺回升，反映整體勞工需求逐步回復，惟總就業人數仍低於疫情前水平。名義工資和勞工收入的按年升幅亦略為加快。另一方面，與去年同期比較，勞動人口於12月略為減少1.5%，部分原因是勞動人口參與率輕微下跌。

# 股市

本港股市在2022年出現大幅波動。承接2021年的下行趨勢，恒生指數加速下跌，在2022年10月31日收報14,687點，是自2009年以來的最低水平（圖4）。股市顯著調整，最初是由市場對本地新冠病毒疫情、美國加息及俄烏局勢的憂慮加劇所觸發，其後由於環球金融狀況收緊及內地新冠病毒疫情導致環球經濟前景轉差，令股市調整幅度進一步擴大。股市在年內最後兩個月重拾一些上升動力，部分受到內地優化防疫抗疫措施所支持。恒生指數於年底收報19,781點，較2021年底顯著下跌15.5%，連續第三年下挫。

# 物業市場

在金融狀況收緊及經濟活動疲弱下，住宅物業市場亦有所受壓。樓價於2022年回落15%（圖4），成交量也大幅縮減39%至45,050宗，創下有紀錄以來的新低。儘管樓價下跌，置業負擔能力仍然偏緊。實際按揭利率於年內由約1.6厘上升至3.375至3.625厘，增加供樓人士的按揭供款負擔。非住宅物業市場亦進一步回軟。在空置率高企下，其價格有所回落，租金亦維持偏軟。

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

受惠於內地與香港全面通關，預期2023年香港經濟增長將由低位復甦。儘管先進經濟體增長預期放緩將繼續拖累香港貨物出口，但內地經濟復甦及跨境陸路貨運限制撤銷，應能為本港經濟提供支持。內地與香港全面通關亦有望令香港入境旅遊及其他服務輸出顯著受惠，並提振本地營商氣氛及資本開支。私人消費亦將會在勞工市場轉強下進一步改善。政府預測2023年全年實質本地生產總值會顯著增長，介乎3.5至5.5%。然而，香港經濟增長前景仍受眾多風險及不明朗因素所影響，並很大程度上取決於美國聯邦儲備局政策利率走勢、全球增長前景、地緣政治局勢持續緊張以及本地入境旅遊的復甦步伐。

# 通脹及勞工市場

展望未來，預期本地通脹將輕微上升，但在各種因素互相抵銷下應保持溫和。儘管外圍價格應會維持高企，但由於部分主要經濟體的經濟活動轉弱及商品價格上行壓力緩和，外圍價格的上升動力或會進一步減弱。同樣地，隨着本地經濟復甦及勞工市場改善，本地成本壓力或會輕微上升，但房屋租金偏軟應繼續在一定程度上抵銷其影響。政府預測2023年全年合計的整體及基本通脹率分別為2.9%及2.5%。另一方面，勞工市場狀況有望隨着本地經濟活動復常而進一步改善。

# 銀行體系表現

香港銀行體系在2022年面對充滿挑戰的宏觀經濟環境，包括年初爆發第五波新冠病毒疫情、地緣政治局勢升溫，以及全球各大央行大幅度加息應對通脹上升等。面對各項挑戰，香港銀行應付裕如，資本及流動性狀況繼續保持充裕。年內銀行體系面對的信貸風險增加，但整體資產質素維持於健康水平。與此同時，利率上升促使銀行淨利息收入增加，但其正面影響因呆壞帳準備金增加及費用與佣金收入減少而被局部抵銷。整體而言，零售銀行盈利較2021年改善。

# 資產質素

銀行體系的特定分類貸款比率由2021年底的0.89%上升至2022年底的1.38%，逾期及經重組貸款比率於同期由0.56%升至0.85%（圖5）。中國內地相關貸款的特定分類貸款比率於2022年底為2.21%，亦較2021年底的0.89%上升。特定分類貸款比率上升，主要是由於部分內地房地產發展商的貸款評級被下調。儘管如此，銀行撥備充足，截至2022年底，銀行信貸撥備覆蓋率（即信貸撥備和特定分類貸款比率）約維持於80%。若將抵押品變現價值從呆壞帳餘額中扣除，銀行信貸撥備覆蓋率約140%。另一方面，2022年底住宅按揭貸款及信用卡貸款的拖欠比率仍然處於低位，分別為0.06%及0.23%（圖6）。

# 盈利走勢

銀行體系在2022年繼續錄得盈利。年內零售銀行的整體除稅前經營溢利上升19.0%（圖7）。盈利改善是受惠於淨利息收入（+34%）及外匯與衍生工具收入增加（+72%），但部分升幅被呆壞帳準備金增加（+151%）及費用與佣金收入減少（–19%）所抵銷。在加息環境下，淨息差由上一年的0.98%擴闊至2022年的1.31%（圖8）。年內市場波動增加，亦令銀行來自外匯及衍生工具業務的收入增加。呆壞帳準備金增加是由於須為新的特定分類貸款預留特殊準備金，而在金融市場表現疲弱下，費用及佣金收入減少。零售銀行成本與收入比率由2021年的54.7%，降至2022年的48.0%（圖9）。

# 資產負債表走勢

2022年銀行體系資產負債表擴大2.5%。資產上升是由於外匯及衍生工具持倉按市價計值增加。面對外圍不明朗因素及利率趨升，年內貸款需求減弱。相比2021年錄得3.8%的增幅，2022年貸款總額減少3.0%。其中在香港境外使用的貸款減少10.2%，貿易融資減少13.5%，在香港使用的貸款則稍增0.9%。中國內地相關貸款繼2021年增長3.7%後，於2022年減少4.4%。

在資產負債表的負債方面，銀行體系存款繼續錄得溫和增長。存款總額於2022年增加1.7%，相比2021年的增幅為4.6%。由於貸款總額減少而存款總額增加，整體貸存比率由2021年底的71.8%稍降至2022年底的68.5%（圖10）。

# 資本充足水平

銀行在2022年的資本狀況維持充裕。2022年底本地註冊認可機構的綜合總資本比率為20.1%，相比上一年為20.2%；一級資本比率為18.1%（圖11）。兩者均遠高於相關國際最低要求。《巴塞爾協定三》槓桿比率於2022年底為7.9%（圖12）。

銀行體系的流動性狀況繼續維持穩健，成為在宏觀經濟環境不明朗因素加劇下的重要支柱。第1類機構的季度平均流動性覆蓋比率在2022年第4季為162.3%，第2類機構的季度平均流動性維持比率為63.2%（圖13）。銀行體系的主要資金來源仍然是客戶存款。於2022年底，第1類機構的穩定資金淨額比率及第2A類機構的核心資金比率分別為137.7%及155.7%（圖14）。以上所有4個比率均遠高於法定最低要求。

# Economy and Finance

Hong Kong’s economy contracted significantly in 2022, facing the fifth wave of the COVID-19 pandemic, tighter financial conditions, and a challenging external environment. The labor market initially weakened before gradually improving, while inflation remained moderate. Asset markets also experienced pressure. With the full resumption of travel between Mainland China and Hong Kong, the Hong Kong economy is expected to rebound from a low level in 2023.

# Economic Performance Review

# Physical Economy Activities

Hong Kong’s economy contracted by 3.5% in 2022, due to a range of adverse factors both locally and externally (Table 1 and Figure 1). Locally, private consumption declined sharply in the first quarter as a result of the fifth wave of COVID-19. It subsequently recovered, supported by the gradual easing of social distancing measures and the government’s consumption voucher scheme. Overall investment spending decreased significantly compared to 2021, reflecting a weak business climate and tighter financial conditions. Externally, Hong Kong’s merchandise exports fell as external demand weakened and cross-border land transport between mainland China and Hong Kong was disrupted. Service exports remained sluggish, largely because tourism was subdued, but improved somewhat in the fourth quarter after the government lifted mandatory quarantine requirements for arrivals in late September.

Local inflation pressures rose slightly in 2022 but remained moderate. Specifically, the core inflation rate gradually increased to 2% by December, partially offset by mild local cost pressures, particularly soft housing rents (Figure 2). The weak economic climate also contributed to subdued wage growth and lower commercial property rents, further limiting inflationary pressures. For the full year of 2022, core and overall inflation rates were 1.7% and 1.9%, respectively.

# Labor Market

The labor market deteriorated sharply in early 2022 but subsequently improved. The unemployment rate peaked at 5.4% in April before declining significantly to 3.5% by December (Figure 3), with unemployment rates falling across most industries. Total employment and private sector job vacancies rebounded, reflecting a gradual recovery in overall labor demand, though employment remains below pre-pandemic levels. Annual growth rates of nominal wages and labor income also accelerated slightly.  Meanwhile, the labor force decreased by 1.5% in December compared to the same period last year, partly due to a slight decline in labor force participation.

# Stock Market

Hong Kong's stock market experienced significant swings in 2022. Continuing the downward trend from 2021, the Hang Seng Index accelerated its decline, reaching 14,687 points on October 31, 2022—its lowest level since 2009 (Figure 4). The market’s downturn was initially driven by concerns over local COVID-19 conditions, rising U.S. interest rates, and the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Subsequently, tighter global financial conditions and the impact of COVID-19 in mainland China further dampened the global economic outlook. In the final two months of the year, the market showed signs of recovery, partly supported by mainland China’s optimized pandemic prevention measures. The Hang Seng Index closed the year at 19,781 points, a 15.5% decrease from the end of 2021, marking the third consecutive year of decline.

# Real Estate Market

The residential property market also came under pressure amid tightening financial conditions and a weak economy. Property prices fell by 15% in 2022 (Figure 4), and transaction volumes decreased sharply by 39% to 45,050 units, reaching a record low. Despite the price decline, affordability remained tight. Mortgage interest rates rose during the year from approximately 1.6% to a range of 3.375% to 3.625%, increasing the burden of mortgage payments for homeowners. The non-residential property market also softened further. High vacancy rates led to price declines and weak rental rates.

Data Source: Rating and Valuation Department and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited

# Economic Prospects

# Economic climate

Hong Kong’s economy is expected to rebound from a low base in 2023, benefiting from the mainland and Hong Kong border reopening. While slower growth in advanced economies will continue to affect Hong Kong’s merchandise exports, the mainland’s economic recovery and the lifting of restrictions on cross-border land cargo transport are expected to provide support. The reopening is also anticipated to significantly boost Hong Kong’s inbound tourism and other service exports, as well as bolster local business confidence and capital expenditure. Private consumption is also projected to improve further as the labor market strengthens. The government forecasts that real GDP will grow significantly in 2023, between 3.5% and 5.5%. However, Hong Kong’s economic growth outlook remains subject to numerous risks and uncertainties, largely depending on the trajectory of U.S. Federal Reserve policy interest rates, global growth prospects, ongoing geopolitical tensions, and the pace of inbound tourism recovery.

# Inflation and the Labor Market

Local inflation is expected to rise slightly but should remain moderate, as various factors will balance each other out. While external prices are likely to stay high, their upward trend may weaken due to slowing economies in major markets and easing pressure on commodity prices. Similarly, local cost pressures may increase slightly as the economy recovers and the labor market improves, but soft residential rents should continue to help offset this effect. The government forecasts overall and core inflation rates of 2.9% and 2.5% for 2023. On the other hand, the labor market is expected to improve further as local economic activity returns to normal.

# State of the Banking System

Hong Kong's banking system navigated a challenging macroeconomic landscape in 2022, contending with the early outbreak of the fifth COVID-19 wave, escalating geopolitical tensions, and substantial interest rate increases by major central banks worldwide aimed at curbing inflation. Despite these headwinds, the banking sector demonstrated resilience, maintaining robust capital and liquidity positions. While credit risk within the system increased throughout the year, overall asset quality remained healthy. Concurrently, higher interest rates bolstered net interest income for banks; however, this gain was partially offset by increased provisions for potential loan losses and a decline in fee and commission revenue. Overall, retail banking profitability improved compared to 2021.

# Asset Assessment

The specific loan classification ratio of the banking system rose from 0.89% at the end of 2021 to 1.38% at the end of 2022, while the ratio of overdue and restructured loans increased from 0.56% to 0.85% during the same period (Figure 5). The ratio for related loans in mainland China was 2.21% at the end of 2022, up from 0.89% at the end of 2021. This increase was primarily due to downgrades in credit ratings for some real estate developers in mainland China. Nevertheless, banks maintained adequate loan loss reserves. As of the end of 2022, the loan loss reserve coverage ratio—the ratio of loan loss reserves to non-performing loans—remained approximately at 80%. After deducting the recoverable value of collateral from non-performing loan balances, this ratio was approximately 140%. On the other hand, delinquency rates for residential mortgage loans and credit card loans remained low at the end of 2022, at 0.06% and 0.23%, respectively (Figure 6).

# Profitability Trend

The banking sector continued to record profits in 2022. Overall pre-tax operating profit for retail banks rose by 19.0% during the year (Figure 7). This improvement was driven by increased net interest income (+34%) and higher revenue from foreign exchange and derivatives (+72%), although this growth was partially offset by increased impairment provisions (+151%) and a decline in fee and commission income (-19%). In a rising interest rate environment, the net interest margin widened from 0.98% in the previous year to 1.31% in 2022 (Figure 8). Increased market volatility also contributed to higher income from foreign exchange and derivatives businesses. The increase in impairment provisions was due to the need to set aside special reserves for newly classified loans, while weaker financial market performance resulted in lower fee and commission income. The cost-to-income ratio for retail banks decreased from 54.7% in 2021 to 48.0% in 2022 (Figure 9).

# Balance Sheet Performance

The banking system’s balance sheet expanded by 2.5% in 2022. This growth was primarily due to an increase in the market value of foreign exchange and derivative holdings. Loan demand weakened during the year, influenced by external uncertainties and rising interest rates. Total loans decreased by 3.0% in 2022, a significant shift from the 3.8% increase recorded in 2021. Loans outside Hong Kong declined by 10.2%, while trade financing decreased by 13.5%. Within Hong Kong, loans increased slightly by 0.9%. Loans to Mainland China decreased by 4.4% in 2022, following a 3.7% increase the previous year.

On the liabilities side of the balance sheet, bank deposits continued to grow moderately. Total deposits increased by 1.7% in 2022, compared to a 4.6% increase in 2021. This growth in deposits, coupled with a decrease in total loans, resulted in a slight decline in the overall loan-to-deposit ratio, from 71.8% at the end of 2021 to 68.5% at the end of 2022 (Figure 10).

# Capital Adequacy Position

The banking sector maintained a sound capital position in 2022. As of the end of 2022, the combined capital adequacy ratio for local financial institutions was 20.1%, compared to 20.2% the previous year; the Tier 1 capital ratio was 18.1% (Figure 11). Both ratios were significantly higher than the relevant international minimum requirements. The Basel III leverage ratio was 7.9% as of the end of 2022 (Figure 12).

# Liquidity Assessment

The banking system’s liquidity position remained robust, serving as a crucial pillar amid heightened uncertainties in the macroeconomic environment. The quarterly average liquidity coverage ratio for Category 1 institutions was 162.3%, while the quarterly average liquidity maintenance ratio for Category 2 institutions was 63.2% (Figure 13). Customer deposits remain the primary source of funding for the banking system. As of the end of 2022, the net stable funding ratio for Category 1 institutions and the core funding ratio for Category 2A institutions were 137.7% and 155.7%, respectively (Figure 14). All four ratios were significantly above the statutory minimum requirements.

# Monetary Stability

As the United States tightened its monetary policy, the Hong Kong dollar weakened in 2022, triggering the exchange rate mechanism 41 times between May and November. Driven by increased trading activity in the Hong Kong stock market and year-end funding demand, the Hong Kong dollar began to strengthen in mid-November. Under the linked exchange rate system, the Hong Kong interbank offered rate (HIBOR) generally followed US interbank rates. Due to continued interest rate hikes in the United States, HIBOR rose steadily throughout 2022. Overall, the Hong Kong dollar’s foreign exchange and money market remained stable, with smooth transactions. As the cornerstone of monetary and financial stability in Hong Kong, the linked exchange rate system has consistently demonstrated a strong ability to withstand external shocks.

# Goals

Hong Kong’s monetary policy primarily aims to maintain currency stability, ensuring the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remains within a range of HK$7.75 to HK$7.85 per US dollar. This system operates as a currency board, requiring the Exchange Fund to hold US dollar reserves that fully back the monetary base. These reserves must be adjusted in direct proportion to any changes in the monetary base.

The monetary base (Table 1) includes:
- Certificates of Indebtedness (fully backing banknotes issued by the three issuing banks);
- Government-issued banknotes and coins in circulation;
- The total balance of settlement accounts held at the HKMA (i.e., total balances); and
- Exchange Fund bills and bonds issued by the HKMA on behalf of the government.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate through an automatic interest rate adjustment mechanism and its firm commitment to the exchange rate guarantee. When the strong (or weak) exchange rate guarantee is triggered, the HKMA will, upon request from banks, sell Hong Kong dollars and buy U.S. dollars at a rate of HK$7.75 per U.S. dollar (or buy Hong Kong dollars and sell U.S. dollars at HK$7.85), increasing (or decreasing) the aggregate balance, which in turn lowers (or raises) Hong Kong dollar interest rates, thereby bringing the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate back within the HK$7.75-7.85 exchange rate range.

# 2022 in Review

# Exchange Rate Stability

The Hong Kong dollar weakened in early 2022, influenced by adjustments in the local stock market, expectations of further U.S. interest rate increases, and carry trades related to the negative interest rate difference between Hong Kong and London interbank rates. Throughout the following months, the Hong Kong dollar remained near the weak exchange rate guarantee level, which was triggered 41 times between May and November.  Trading activity in the local stock market increased, and seasonal funding demand rose at year-end, prompting the Hong Kong dollar to strengthen from mid-November (see Figure 1). Overall, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange market continued to operate normally throughout 2022.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) issued an additional HK$40 billion in Exchange Fund Bills at the beginning of 2022 to meet continued demand from banks. Between May and November 2022, the HKMA purchased a total of HK$242.1 billion under the Linked Exchange Rate System, intervening to support the Hong Kong dollar at the weak-side convertibility point in response to bank requests. As a result, total reserves decreased from HK$3,775 billion at the end of 2021 to HK$963 billion at the end of 2022, reflecting both the issuance of Exchange Fund Bills and the triggering of the weak-side convertibility arrangement. During the year, the total outstanding amount of Exchange Fund Bills and bonds increased slightly, from HK$11,488 billion to HK$12,004 billion. Consequently, the combined total of total reserves and outstanding Exchange Fund Bills and bonds decreased from HK$15,263 billion at the end of 2021 to HK$12,967 billion at the end of 2022 (Figure 2). The overall monetary base remained fully supported by foreign exchange reserves.

Figure 1: 2022 Market Exchange Rates

Figure 2: 2022 Net Balance (Prior to Discount Window Operations) and Outstanding Foreign Exchange Fund Notes and Bonds

# Money Market

Under the Linked Exchange Rate System, the Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate (HIBOR) generally follows the trend of the US dollar interbank offered rate. As the United States continued to raise interest rates in 2022, HIBOR gradually increased (Figure 3). For the year, overnight, one-month, and three-month HIBOR rose by 318, 419, and 473 basis points, respectively, reaching 3.23%, 4.35%, and 4.99% by year-end.

In response to increases in the U.S. Federal Funds rate target range, the benchmark rate was raised seven times, totaling 4.25 percentage points (equivalent to 425 basis points), rising from 0.5% to 4.75% (Figure 3). At the retail level, several banks increased their prime lending rates by 12.5 basis points in late September, followed by further increases of 25 basis points in early November and mid-December. Some banks also raised the upper limit for new mortgage interest rates based on the Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate (HIBOR) during the year. Overall, the Hong Kong money market continued to operate smoothly. Discount window lending increased from HKD 6.8 billion in 2021 to HKD 8.4 billion in 2022.

Figure 3: Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate (2022)

# Linked Exchange Rate Regime

For nearly 40 years, the Linked Exchange Rate System has been a vital pillar of Hong Kong’s financial system, demonstrating a strong ability to respond to challenges. Despite volatile global financial conditions in 2022, the Hong Kong dollar’s foreign exchange and money markets continued to operate in an orderly manner, reflecting the system’s stability and effectiveness. The government remains resolutely committed to maintaining the system. The International Monetary Fund, in its “2022 External Sector Report,” repeatedly affirmed that Hong Kong possesses transparent rules, substantial fiscal and foreign exchange reserves, robust financial regulation and supervision, a flexible economy, and prudent fiscal arrangements, all of which ensure the credibility of the Linked Exchange Rate System.

A sound banking system plays a crucial role in the normal functioning of the linked exchange rate system. Hong Kong's banking system continues to operate smoothly, with liquidity and capital positions well above international standards. To ensure the banking system’s resilience, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has been scrutinizing banks' credit, liquidity, and interest rate risk management, as well as stress test results, and maintains oversight of bank lending.

To enhance the transparency of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's accounts, since October 1998, certain assets of the Exchange Fund have been designated to support the monetary base. The support ratio (the ratio of supporting assets to the monetary base) fluctuated between 109.3% and 111.0% in 2022, without reaching either the upper or lower limits. The ratio closed at 110.1% on December 31 (Figure 4). Under the Linked Exchange Rate System, although certain Exchange Fund assets have been designated for support, all Exchange Fund assets can be used to support the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate. The Exchange Fund's substantial financial resources, combined with Hong Kong's robust banking system, provide a strong backing for the monetary and financial stability of Hong Kong.

Figure 4: Daily Fluctuation of Support Ratio in 2022

# Currency Management Committee

The Currency Board, under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, is responsible for monitoring and examining issues related to Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability. In 2022, its discussions included the property market situation in mainland China, the role of non-bank institutions in the residential mortgage market, the application of deep learning in credit risk assessment, and a monitoring framework for assessing Hong Kong dollar liquidity. Meeting minutes and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s reports on the Currency Board’s operations are available on the HKMA website.

# Hong Kong Banknotes

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to hold seminars to educate bank counter staff, retail cashiers, and students about the design and security features of Hong Kong banknotes, enhancing their knowledge and skills in identifying banknotes. In 2022, the HKMA held 15 seminars, attracting over 4,200 participants.

# Physical Currency Collection Plan

The coin collection program continues to be popular among citizens. Details of the program are included in the "Sustainable Development Initiatives of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority" chapter of the 2022 Sustainable Development Report.

# Foreign Exchange Fund Notes and Bonds

The Exchange Fund Bills and Bonds Programme continued to operate smoothly. To meet sustained demand from banks for Exchange Fund Bills and taking into account market conditions, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued a total of HK$40 billion in Exchange Fund Bills during the first two months of 2022, resulting in a corresponding decrease in the outstanding balance. As of the end of 2022, the outstanding nominal value of Exchange Fund Bills and Bonds totalled approximately HK$1,207.5 billion (Table 2).
